title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: AICcPermanova package provides R implementation model selection Permanovas vegan package. package enables users generate possible models given set variables, calculate AICc values models, perform model selection based given threshold.

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: install package, can use remotes package install development version: Alternatively, can install stable version CRAN:
code: remotes::install_github("Sustainscapes/AICcPerm") install.packages("AICcPermanova")

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: generate possible models, can use make_models function. example: function create table possible models specified variables, can see following table: can see possible models 3 variables.
code: library(AICcPermanova) AllModels <- make_models(vars = c("pH", "Sand", "Clay"), ncores = 2)

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: calculate AICc, can use AICc_permanova2 function. ’s example use : results calculation displayed following table: example, used adonis2 function run PERMANOVA analysis dune dataset Management A1 variables. calculated AICc using AICc_permanova2 function
code: library(vegan) #> Loading required package: permute #> Loading required package: lattice #> This is vegan 2.6-4 data(dune) data(dune.env)  # Run PERMANOVA using adonis2  Model <- adonis2(dune ~ Management*A1, data = dune.env)  # Calculate AICc Table_permanova <- AICc_permanova2(Model) knitr::kable(Table_permanova)

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: section, ’ll provide complete example AICcPerm package workflow. First, need load datasets vegan package: Next, ’ll generate possible first-order models dataset: results 32 possible models, shown following table:
code: library(vegan) data(dune) data(dune.env) AllModels <- make_models(vars = c("A1", "Moisture", "Management", "Use", "Manure")) #> 1 of 5 ready 2023-04-10 17:46:01 #> 2 of 5 ready 2023-04-10 17:46:05 #> 3 of 5 ready 2023-04-10 17:46:09 #> 4 of 5 ready 2023-04-10 17:46:13 #> 5 of 5 ready 2023-04-10 17:46:15

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: generating models, ’s important check multicollinearity. can use filter_vif function filter models high degree collinearity (defined maximum value VIF 5 ): reduces number models 21
code: NonColinear <- filter_vif(all_forms = AllModels, env_data = dune.env)

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: filtering collinear models, can fit remaining non-collinear models using fit_models function: results table fitted models ordered AICc, displayed : block variable used (Use dune.env object), can specify using strata argument: results table fitted models takes account block variable, displayed :
code: Fitted <- fit_models(all_forms = NonColinear,            veg_data = dune,            env_data = dune.env,            ncores = 4,            method = "bray") Fitted2 <- fit_models(all_forms = NonColinear,            veg_data = dune,            env_data = dune.env,            ncores = 4,            method = "bray",            strata = "Use")

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: select models, use select_models function, chooses models maximum VIF less 5 delta AICc less specified threshold, delta_aicc. default, delta_aicc set 2. can use Fitted2 object generated previous section select models: resulting table displays selected models: Note models table satisfy criteria maximum VIF delta AICc specified select_models function.
code: Selected <- select_models(Fitted2)

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: finally can summarized r squared weighted AICc using akaike_adjusted_rsq function seen bellow: results following table:
code: Summary <- akaike_adjusted_rsq(Selected)

title: Getting started with the AICcPermanova package
text: AICcPerm package provides easy--use implementation model selection based AICc, useful tool selecting best model set candidate models. calculating AICc values model, can compare select model lowest AICc value. method takes account model complexity goodness--fit, making valuable approach selecting models balance two factors. Furthermore, AICcPermanova package offers additional tools model selection, model averaging model comparison based likelihood ratio tests. can used refine model selection improve accuracy model predictions. Overall, AICcPermanova package powerful tool model selection variety contexts, including ecology, biology, fields use statistical modeling analyze complex data. selecting best model set candidate models, researchers can make accurate predictions draw reliable conclusions data.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Derek Corcoran. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Corcoran D (2023). AICcPermanova: Model Selection PERMANOVA Models Using AICc. https://github.com/Sustainscapes/AICcPerm, https://sustainscapes.github.io/AICcPerm/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {AICcPermanova: Model Selection of PERMANOVA Models Using AICc},   author = {Derek Corcoran},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/Sustainscapes/AICcPerm, https://sustainscapes.github.io/AICcPerm/}, }

title: Model Selection of PERMANOVA Models Using AICc
text: AICcPermanova package provides R implementation model selection Permanovas vegan package. package enables users generate possible models given set variables, calculate AICc values models, perform model selection based given threshold.

code: remotes::install_github("Sustainscapes/AICcPerm") install.packages("AICcPermanova")

text: generate possible models, can use make_models function. example: function create table possible models specified variables, can see following table: can see possible models 3 variables.
code: library(AICcPermanova) AllModels <- make_models(vars = c("pH", "Sand", "Clay"), ncores = 2)

code: library(vegan) #> Loading required package: permute #> Loading required package: lattice #> This is vegan 2.6-4 data(dune) data(dune.env)  # Run PERMANOVA using adonis2  Model <- adonis2(dune ~ Management*A1, data = dune.env)  # Calculate AICc Table_permanova <- AICc_permanova2(Model) knitr::kable(Table_permanova)

title: Model Selection of PERMANOVA Models Using AICc
text: filtering collinear models, can fit remaining non-collinear models using fit_models function: results table fitted models ordered AICc, displayed : block variable used (Use dune.env object), can specify using strata argument: results table fitted models takes account block variable, displayed :
code: Fitted <- fit_models(all_forms = NonColinear,            veg_data = dune,            env_data = dune.env,            ncores = 4,            method = "bray") Fitted2 <- fit_models(all_forms = NonColinear,            veg_data = dune,            env_data = dune.env,            ncores = 4,            method = "bray",            strata = "Use")

what: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
text: #' function calculates Akaike's Information Criterion (AICc) permutational multivariate analysis variance (PERMANOVA) model. AICc modified version Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) appropriate small sample sizes high-dimensional models.

title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
code: AICc_permanova2(adonis2_model)

title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
text: adonis2_model object class adonis2 vegan package

title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
text: data frame AICc, number parameters (k) number observations (N).

title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
text: AICc calculation PERMANOVA model : $$AICc = AIC + \frac{2k(k+1)}{n-k-1}$$ AIC Akaike Information Criterion, k number parameters model (excluding intercept), n number observations.

title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
text: Zuur, . F., Ieno, E. N., Walker, N. J., Saveliev, . ., & Smith, G. M. (2009). Mixed effects models extensions ecology R. Springer Science & Business Media.

title: Calculate AICc for a permutational multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) — AICc_permanova2
code: library(vegan) #> Loading required package: permute #> Loading required package: lattice #> This is vegan 2.6-4 data(dune) data(dune.env)  # Run PERMANOVA using adonis2  Model <- adonis2(dune ~ Management*A1, data = dune.env)  # Calculate AICc AICc_permanova2(Model) #>        AICc k  N #> 1 -19.06395 8 20

what: Get Maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) from a Model — VIF
title: Get Maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) from a Model — VIF
text: function calculates maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) given model. VIF measure collinearity among predictor variables within regression model. quantifies much variance estimated regression coefficient increased due collinearity. VIF 1 indicates collinearity, values 1 indicate increasing levels collinearity. VIF 5 greater often considered high, indicating strong presence collinearity.

title: Get Maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) from a Model — VIF
code: VIF(model)

title: Get Maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) from a Model — VIF
text: model regression model, created lm, glm, similar functions.

title: Get Maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) from a Model — VIF
text: maximum VIF value.

title: Get Maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) from a Model — VIF
text: Belsley, D. ., Kuh, E., & Welsch, R. E. (1980). Regression Diagnostics: Identifying Influential Data Sources Collinearity. John Wiley & Sons. Kutner, M. H., Nachtsheim, C. J., Neter, J., & Li, W. (2004). Applied Linear Statistical Models. McGraw-Hill/Irwin. O'Brien, R. M. (2007). caution regarding rules thumb variance inflation factors. Quality & Quantity, 41(5), 673-690.

what: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
title: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
text: Calculates adjusted R squared predictor using Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) model averaging. AIC used compare performance candidate models select best one. , R squared adjusted based weight evidence favor model. final result long-format table variable names corresponding adjusted R squared values.

title: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
code: akaike_adjusted_rsq(DF)

title: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
text: DF data.frame containing variables calculate adjusted R squared . data.frame include columns: "form", "AICc", "max_vif", "k", "DeltaAICc", "AICWeight", "N".

title: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
text: data.frame columns "Variable" "Full_Akaike_Adjusted_RSq". row represents predictor, corresponding adjusted R squared value based Akaike-adjusted model averaging process.

title: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
text: adjusted R squared calculated : $$Adjusted R^2 = 1 - (RSS / (N - k - 1)) * ((N - 1) / (N - k - 1))$$ RSS residual sum squares, N sample size, k number predictors. R squared adjusted based weight evidence favor model, calculated : $$w_i = exp(-0.5 * DeltaAICc_i) / sum(exp(-0.5 * DeltaAICc))$$ w_i weight evidence favor ith model, DeltaAICc_i difference AICc ith model best model. Model averaging uses weights combine performance different models final calculation adjusted R squared.

title: Akaike-Adjusted R Squared Calculation with Model Averaging — akaike_adjusted_rsq
code: library(data.table) df <- data.table(form = c(1,2,3),                  AICc = c(10,20,30),                  max_vif = c(3,4,5),                  k = c(1,2,3),                  DeltaAICc = c(2,5,8),                  AICWeight = c(0.2,0.5,0.3),                  N = c(100,100,100),                  A1 = c(0.3, 0.5, NA),                  A2 = c(0.7, NA, 0.2),                  A3 = c(0.2, 0.3, 0.6)) akaike_adjusted_rsq(df) #> # A tibble: 4 × 2 #>   Variable Full_Akaike_Adjusted_RSq #>   <chr>                       <dbl> #> 1 form                         6    #> 2 A1                           0.31 #> 3 A2                           0.2  #> 4 A3                           0.37

what: Filters out equations with high multicollinearity — filter_vif
title: Filters out equations with high multicollinearity — filter_vif
text: function takes dataframe several models calculates maximum Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) given model. either filters ones high collinearity flags accordingly

title: Filters out equations with high multicollinearity — filter_vif
code: filter_vif(all_forms, env_data, ncores = 2, filter = TRUE, verbose = TRUE)

title: Filters out equations with high multicollinearity — filter_vif
text: all_forms data frame generated make_models env_data dataset variables described all_froms ncores integer specifying number cores use parallel processing filter logical, TRUE filters models maximum VIF high higher, FALSE generates new column called collinearity, wich verbose logical, defaults TRUE, sends messages processing times

title: Filters out equations with high multicollinearity — filter_vif
text: data.frame models, fitering ones high collinearity flagginf .

title: Filters out equations with high multicollinearity — filter_vif
code: # \donttest{ library(vegan) data(dune) data(dune.env) AllModels <- make_models(vars = c("A1", "Moisture", "Manure")) #> 1 of 3 ready 2023-04-10 17:44:57 #> 2 of 3 ready 2023-04-10 17:45:01 #> 3 of 3 ready 2023-04-10 17:45:03  filter_vif(all_forms = AllModels,            env_data = dune.env) #>                                form  max_vif #> 1                     Distance ~ A1 0.000000 #> 2               Distance ~ Moisture 0.000000 #> 3                 Distance ~ Manure 0.000000 #> 4          Distance ~ A1 + Moisture 3.000000 #> 5            Distance ~ A1 + Manure 4.000000 #> 6      Distance ~ Moisture + Manure 4.000000 #> 7 Distance ~ A1 + Moisture + Manure 4.508169 #> 8                      Distance ~ 1 0.000000 # }

what: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
title: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
text: function fits PERMANOVA models combinations variables given dataset, arranges models Akaike Information Criterion (AICc) score. function also calculates maximum variance inflation factor (max_vif) model.

title: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
code: fit_models(   all_forms,   veg_data,   env_data,   method = "bray",   ncores = 2,   log = TRUE,   logfile = "log.txt",   multiple = 100,   strata = NULL,   verbose = FALSE )

title: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
text: all_forms data frame generated make_models veg_data dataset vegetation presence absense abundance data env_data dataset variables described all_froms method method distance vegdist ncores integer specifying number cores use parallel processing log logical true, log file generated logfile text file generated log multiple many loops write log file strata block variable similar use adonis2 verbose logical, defaults TRUE, sends messages processing times

title: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
text: data.frame fitted models arranged AICc, including formula used, number explanatory variables, R2, adjusted R2, AICc max VIF.

title: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
text: Anderson, M. J. (2001). new method non-parametric multivariate analysis variance. Austral Ecology, 26(1), 32-46. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1442-9993.2001.01070.pp.x

title: Fit PERMANOVA models and arrange by AICc — fit_models
code: # \donttest{ library(vegan) data(dune) data(dune.env)  AllModels <- make_models(vars = c("A1", "Moisture", "Manure")) #> 1 of 3 ready 2023-04-10 17:45:10 #> 2 of 3 ready 2023-04-10 17:45:14 #> 3 of 3 ready 2023-04-10 17:45:16  fit_models(all_forms = AllModels,            veg_data = dune,            env_data = dune.env) #>                                form  max_vif      AICc k  N         A1 #> 1               Distance ~ Moisture 0.000000 -30.36319 4 20         NA #> 2                     Distance ~ A1 0.000000 -29.72347 2 20 0.16816657 #> 3                      Distance ~ 1 0.000000 -28.52467 1 20         NA #> 4          Distance ~ A1 + Moisture 3.000000 -28.21149 5 20 0.04230343 #> 5                 Distance ~ Manure 0.000000 -25.21490 5 20         NA #> 6            Distance ~ A1 + Manure 4.000000 -25.18745 6 20 0.12092088 #> 7      Distance ~ Moisture + Manure 4.000000 -22.93984 8 20         NA #> 8 Distance ~ A1 + Moisture + Manure 4.508169 -18.59078 9 20 0.04145173 #>    Moisture    Manure Model #> 1 0.4019903        NA    NA #> 2        NA        NA    NA #> 3        NA        NA     0 #> 4 0.2761272        NA    NA #> 5        NA 0.3544714    NA #> 6        NA 0.3072258    NA #> 7 0.3005223 0.2530035    NA #> 8 0.2210532 0.2521518    NA # }

what: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
title: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
text: Generates possible linear models given set predictor variables using distance matrix response variable. function allows user specify maximum number variables model, can useful cases many predictors. output data frame containing possible models, can passed fit_models function fitting using PERMANOVA approach.

title: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
code: make_models(vars, ncores = 2, k = NULL, verbose = TRUE)

title: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
text: vars character vector variables use modeling ncores integer specifying number cores use parallel processing k maximum number variables model, default NULL verbose logical, defaults TRUE, sends messages processing times

title: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
text: data frame containing possible linear permanova models

title: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
text: Anderson, M. J. (2001). new method non-parametric multivariate analysis variance. Austral Ecology, 26(1), 32-46.

title: Create models with different combinations of variables — make_models
code: # \donttest{ make_models(vars = c("A", "B", "C", "D"),             ncores = 2, verbose = FALSE) #>                        form #> 1              Distance ~ A #> 2              Distance ~ B #> 3              Distance ~ C #> 4              Distance ~ D #> 5          Distance ~ A + B #> 6          Distance ~ A + C #> 7          Distance ~ A + D #> 8          Distance ~ B + C #> 9          Distance ~ B + D #> 10         Distance ~ C + D #> 11     Distance ~ A + B + C #> 12     Distance ~ A + B + D #> 13     Distance ~ A + C + D #> 14     Distance ~ B + C + D #> 15 Distance ~ A + B + C + D #> 16             Distance ~ 1  # using k as a way to limit number of variables make_models(vars = c("A", "B", "C", "D"),             ncores = 2, k = 2, verbose = FALSE) #>                form #> 1      Distance ~ A #> 2      Distance ~ B #> 3      Distance ~ C #> 4      Distance ~ D #> 5  Distance ~ A + B #> 6  Distance ~ A + C #> 7  Distance ~ A + D #> 8  Distance ~ B + C #> 9  Distance ~ B + D #> 10 Distance ~ C + D #> 11     Distance ~ 1 # }

what: Select models based on AICc and VIF. — select_models
title: Select models based on AICc and VIF. — select_models
text: function selects models data frame based AICc VIF values. Models AICc greater negative infinity VIF less equal 6 considered. difference AICc values model calculated respect model minimum AICc. Models difference AICc less equal specified delta_aicc value selected.

title: Select models based on AICc and VIF. — select_models
code: select_models(df, delta_aicc = 2)

title: Select models based on AICc and VIF. — select_models
text: df data frame containing models select . delta_aicc numeric value specifying maximum difference AICc values allowed.

title: Select models based on AICc and VIF. — select_models
text: data frame containing selected models AIC weights.

title: Select models based on AICc and VIF. — select_models
code: df <- data.frame(AICc = c(10, 12, 15, 20), max_vif = c(2, 4, 5, 6)) select_models(df) #>   AICc max_vif DeltaAICc AICWeight #> 1   10       2         0 0.7310586 #> 2   12       4         2 0.2689414 select_models(df, delta_aicc = 5) #>   AICc max_vif DeltaAICc  AICWeight #> 1   10       2         0 0.68967209 #> 2   12       4         2 0.25371618 #> 3   15       5         5 0.05661173
